Comments_List: I learned more about the history of the American continents, including the development of financial, political, and labor institutions from the time of European settlement.
Insights on history of institutions, political system, etc. focusing on how they affected economic or social development.

I got familiar with reading papers that have a different type of tone than the typical economics paper, with thinking through what topics from history might be relevant to my research interests (development economics) and on crafting discussions of papers that are a bit more narrative (rather than econ math-style)-based

For international students, sometimes is difficult to follow the topics about US history. I did not know anything about cotton or the civil war, so sometimes I felt that we were supposed to know more. Overall, I really liked the course.
I liked the idea of studying the same topics alternately between the U.S. and Latin America.
Strength: Provide basic knowledge for a wide range of economic-historical issues.

In general, I thought the course was well done. Sometimes when I was reading papers it wasn't immediately clear what I should be expected to take away from them. A good example was the Morgan Henderson paper--I worked really hard to grind through it and understand the model, only for Naomi to say "this paper was bad, I just wanted you to know they added and took away non-citizen voting rights." Obviously part of becoming a scholar is learning how to prioritize, but when working through a general research area that isn't my primary interest (and so thus I couldn't just use "will I do research here?" as a barometer) it would've been useful to have a bit of a clearer sense on what to focus on.

This course should be recommended not only for would-be economic historians but also for economics students thinking of majoring in labor economics or other fields of empirical economics. The intensive reading will offer students some good research questions.
Yes, I think Naomi and Jose did a good job of teaching the course
